user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_default_log_handler:
```c
void metal_default_log_handler(enum metal_log_level level,
			       const char *format, ...)
{
#ifdef DEFAULT_LOGGER_ON
	char msg[1024];
	va_list args;
	static const char * const level_strs[] = {
		"metal: emergency: ",
		"metal: alert:     ",
		"metal: critical:  ",
		"metal: error:     ",
		"metal: warning:   ",
		"metal: notice:    ",
		"metal: info:      ",
		"metal: debug:     ",
	};

	va_start(args, format);
	vsnprintf(msg, sizeof(msg), format, args);
	va_end(args);

	if (level <= METAL_LOG_EMERGENCY || level > METAL_LOG_DEBUG)
		level = METAL_LOG_EMERGENCY;

	fprintf(stderr, "%s%s", level_strs[level], msg);
#else
	(void)level;
	(void)format;
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_default_log_handler:
enum metal_log_level {
	METAL_LOG_EMERGENCY,	/**< system is unusable.               */
	METAL_LOG_ALERT,	/**< action must be taken immediately. */
	METAL_LOG_CRITICAL,	/**< critical conditions.              */
	METAL_LOG_ERROR,	/**< error conditions.                 */
	METAL_LOG_WARNING,	/**< warning conditions.               */
	METAL_LOG_NOTICE,	/**< normal but significant condition. */
	METAL_LOG_INFO,		/**< informational messages.           */
	METAL_LOG_DEBUG,	/**< debug-level messages.             */
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No calls to the Standard Library string.h functions listed by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (e.g. memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn) are present in the provided function. Therefore Rule 21.17 is not directly applicable and there are no code fragments that need investigation under that specific rule.

Relevant string operations in the function have been reviewed and do not require reporting under Rule 21.17:
- vsnprintf(msg, sizeof(msg), format, args);  // vsnprintf is from <stdio.h>, not <string.h>. The call provides the buffer size (sizeof(msg) == 1024) so it will not write beyond msg and guarantees null-termination when size > 0.
- level_strs[level] used in fprintf after a bounds check: the code normalizes level to METAL_LOG_EMERGENCY when level is outside the valid range, ensuring the index into level_strs is within 0..METAL_LOG_DEBUG. The level validation occurs before the array access in fprintf. The level_strs array contains string literals (valid null-terminated char pointers).
- fprintf(stderr, "%s%s", level_strs[level], msg);  // fprintf is in <stdio.h>, not <string.h>. The pointers passed are to valid null-terminated strings (string literals and the vsnprintf buffer).

Additional housekeeping (va_start/va_end) is used correctly.

Given the absence of string.h function calls and the safe handling of string buffers and array indexing in this fragment, no suspicious fragments are reported for investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.
